item.content:
By default, JavaScript is a** synchronous, blocking, single-threaded** language

  • Synchronous: executing one thing at a time
  • Single-threaded: executing the code line by line

Issue of Being Synchronous

When we are working on a big application with a lot of server requests, being synchronous will slow down the application.

console.log("Start")

 for (let i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
   console.log(i)
 }
 console.log("End")
 /* Start
 0
 1
 2
 3
 4
 ...
 18
 19
 End */

Solution: Asynchrnous Model of Programming/Multi-Threaded

With an asynchronous model, JavaScript can perform multiple tasks simultaneously; we don’t need to wait for the current execution to finish before moving on to the next one.

JavaScript can be manipulated to behave in asynchronously with Async/Await, Promises, and Callbacks.

JavaScript is also an asynchronous, non-blocking, multi-threaded language.

Behind the Scene of Asynchronous Code

  • JavaScript engines have Web APIs that are responsible for handling the asynchronous code in the background.
  • The call stack recognizes functions like Async/Await, setTimeout() of the Web API, and they are passed to be handled by the browser.
  • Once those tasks are finished by the browser, they return and are pushed onto the stack as a callback.

Example 1: setTimeout()

setTimeout() delays the execution of a function.

The first argument is the callback function and the other is the time in milliseconds.

console.log("Start");

setTimeout(() => {
  console.log("Middle");
}, 1000)

console.log("End");

// Output:
// Start
// End
// Middle
  1. First on the stack: console.log("Start");
  2. 🔔 The engine notices setTimeout(), but this is handled asynchronously by the Web API, not by JavaScript!
  3. The call stack skips this code block handed off to the Web API, moving on to console.log("End");.
  • setTimeout() will be logged after End even if the time interval is changed to zero seconds.
  • This process of skipping the asynchrnous code block and moving on to the next line of code without blocking the execution of code makes JavaScript Non-Blocking.

Example 2: addEventListener()

window.onload = function() {
  document.querySelector("callback-btn")
    .addEventListener("click", function() { // callback fn
      console.log("User has clicked on the button!");
    });
}

Callbakcs

  • Callback is a function that is is passed as an argument to another function.
  • Its execution is delayed until that function in which it is passed is executed.
  • Callbacks are a fundamental part of Functional Programming.
  • Useful for short asynchronous operations where two or max. three nested callbacks are used.
  • Methods like .map(), .filter(), and .reduce() uses callback functions.

Anonymous Callback Function

const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

const newArr = arr.map(elem => {
  return elem * elem;
})

console.log(newArr);

Named Callback Function

  • By making a new function with the same logic, square(), and referencing it inside .map()
  • Note: square() is passed as an argument inside .map(); it’s not being called! That’s why it’s arr.map(square); and not arr.map(square());
const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

const square = (num) => { return num*num };

const newArr = arr.map(square);

console.log(newArr);

References

“Chapter 11: Asynchrnous Programming”, Eloquent JavaScript

“async function”, MDN Web Docs

“HTML: Living Standard”

jsmanifest, “Callbacks vs. Promises in JavaScript”, Medium, December 3, 2019.

Singh, Ashutosh K. “Synchronous vs Asynchronous Programming,” Medium, September 12, 2020.

item.content:
Define

Primitives: number, string, Boolean, undefined, null, symbol and BigInt.

References: objects (object literal, arrays, functions)

A side note on Numbers

Numbers in JavaScript are treated with a floating point precision!

Qs. What will the code below output? Explain your answer.

console.log(0.1 + 0.2);
console.log(0.1 + 0.2 = 0.3);

“You can’t be sure. It might print out 0.3 and true, or not. Numbers in JavaScript are all treated with floating point precision, and as much, may not always yield the expected results. Surpirsingly though, it will print out 0.30000000000000004 and false.”

Memory Management

JavaScript engine has two components:

  1. The call stack where functions are executed
    • All primitive types are stored in the call stack, as that’s where the execution context runs.
  2. The heap where objects are stored in memory
    • All reference types (object) get stored in the memory heap.

The Process: Primitive Types in Call Stack

let age = 30;
let oldAge = age;
age = 31;
  • let age = 30;:
    1. JavaScript engine creates a unique identifier with the variable name.
    2. The piece of memory will be allocated with a certain address, e.g. 0241.
    3. Finally, the value 30 will be stored in memory at the specified address 0241.

The identifier points to the address, not the value itself.

  • let oldAge = age;:

    1. oldAge simply points to the same memory address as the age variable

  • age = 31;

    1. Certain memory address is immutable, so a new piece of memory is allocated.
    2. The age identifier now points to the new address, 0242 which holds the new value of 31.

The Process: Reference Types in Heap

let age = 30;
let oldAge = age;
age = 31;

const tom = {
  name: 'Tom',
  age: 30
};

const friend = tom;

friend.age = 28;

console.log('Friend: ', friend);
// logs { name: 'Tom', age: 28 }
console.log('Tom: ', tom);
// logs { name: 'Tom', age: 28 }
  • const tom = { /.../ };:
    1. Stored in the heap with a memory address and the value itself.

The object identifier (e.g. tom) does not point directly to the newly created memory address in the heap. Instead, tom will point to a new piece of memory that’s created in the call stack. This new memory in the call stack has a specified address (0243) and a value. It’s this value that points to the memory address in the heap to reference the value of the object.

  • const friend = tom;:

    1. friend identifier points to the same memory addrss as john identifier in the call stack.
    2. Again, that address contains the reference which points to the object stored in the heap.

  • friend.age = 28;

    1. The object stored in the heap changes its age value from 28 to 30.

Even if tom and friend were defined as const, we can still manipulate the object, because we are not changing the value in memory in the call stack. We are changing the reference in the heap. const are immutable for primitive values, but that’s not always the case for reference values.

Remember, we are actually not just copying an object. We are creating a new variable that points to the same object.

item.description: Prompt You are given two non-empty linked lists representing two non-negative integers. The digits are stored in reverse order, and each of their nodes contains a single digit. Add the two numbers and return the sum as a linked list. You may assume the two numbers do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself. Example 1: Input: l1 = [2,4,3], l2 = [5,6,4] Output: [7,0,8] Explanation: 342 + 465 = 807.
item.content:
Prompt

You are given two non-empty linked lists representing two non-negative integers. The digits are stored in reverse order, and each of their nodes contains a single digit. Add the two numbers and return the sum as a linked list.

You may assume the two numbers do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself.

Example 1: Input: l1 = [2,4,3], l2 = [5,6,4] Output: [7,0,8] Explanation: 342 + 465 = 807.

Example 2: Input: l1 = [0], l2 = [0] Output: [0]

Example 3: Input: l1 = [9,9,9,9,9,9,9], l2 = [9,9,9,9] Output: [8,9,9,9,0,0,0,1]

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in each linked list is in the range [1, 100].
  • 0 <= Node.val <= 9
  • It is guaranteed that the list represents a number that does not have leading zeros.

Definition for singly-linked list:

function ListNode(val, next) {
  this.val = (val===undefined ? 0 : val)
  this.next = (next===undefined ? null : next)
}

Linked List

  • Data structure similar to an array, but linked list’s elements are not stored in a particular location or index.
  • Each element (node) is a separate object that stores two properties:
    1. value property with any valid JS data types (string, number, boolean, objects)
    2. next property that points to the next node
  • The head: The entry point or the first node in the linked list
  • NULL: The last node points to null. If a list is empty, the head is a null reference.

Advantage

  • Better than array because we can easily remove or add from a linked list without reorganizing the entire data structure.

Disadvantage

  1. Slow search operations:
  • Because it doesn’t store the index of its values, we need to traverse the entire linked list from the head to the tail.
  • Unliked arrays, random access at a specific index is not allowed.
  1. Uses more memory:
  • Than arrays, because of the storage of the pointers
const list = {
  head: {
    value: 6 // first value = head
    next: { // pointer
      value: 10 // second value
      next: { // pointer
        value: 12 // third value
        next: { // pointer
          value: 3 // fourth value
          next: null // last value's pointer = null
        }
      }
    }
  }
};

Types of Linked List

  1. Singly Linked Lists
  • Each node contains only one pointer to the next node: next
  1. Doubly Linked Lists
  • Each node contains two pointers, a pointer to the next node and a pointer to the previous node: next and previous
  1. Circular Linked Lists
  • A variation of a linked list in which the last node points to the first node or any other node before it, thereby forming a loop: tail points to head

Implemeneting in JavaScript

  1. A function to create a template of a node
function createNode(value) {
  return {
    value: value,
    next: null
  };
}

let newNode = createNode("Hello");
// { value: "Hello", next: null }
  1. Using class to creating and adding a node to a linked list
function createNode(value) {
  return {
    value: value,
    next: null
  };
}

class List {
  constructor() {
    this.head = null;
    this.tail = null;
  }

  append(value) {
    let node = createNode(value);

    //is it current empty?
    if(!this.tail) {
      // then head and tail are the same
      this.head = this.tail = node;
      return node;
    }

    // if it's not empty, track this on the end
    // and update `tail` to point at this new node
    this.tail.next = node;
    this.tail = node;

    // return the node we added
    return node;
  }

  print() {
    let current = this.head;
    while(current) {
      console.log(current.value);
      current = current.next;
    }
  }
}

let test = new List(); // starts off with an empty list
test.append(2);
test.append(4);
test.append(3);
test.print(); // 2 4 3

// test =
List {
  head: {
    value: 2,
    next: {
      value: 4,
      next: {
        /.../
      }
    }
  },
  tail: {
    value: 3,
    next: null
  }
}

// [2, 4, 3] is:
// [test.head.value, test.head.next.value, test.head.next.next.value]

Linked List Methods

  1. size(): returns the number of nodes present
size() {
  let count = 0;
  let node = this.head;
  while (node) {
    count++;
    node = node.next;
  }
  return count;
}
  1. clear(): empties out the list
clear() {
  this.head = null;
}
  1. getLast(): returns the last node
getLast() {
  let lastNode = this.head;
  if (lastNode) {
    while (lastNode.next) {
      lastNode = lastNode.next;
    }
  }
  return lastNode;
}
  1. getFirst(): returns the first node
getFirst() {
  return this.head;
}

Using Linked List to Problem Solve

  • Each element from l1 and l2 are added
  • If the summation is equal to or greater than 10, divide it by 10: its remainder is set as the current digit and the ‘overflow’ num is carried over to the next iteration.
    • e.g. if result is 12, 2 is set as the current digit and 1 is carried over.
    • carry must be either 0 or 1, because the largest possible sum of the two digits plus a carry is 9 + 9 + 1 = 19.
var addTwoNumbers = function(l1, l2) {
    let carry = 0;
    const root = new ListNode(null);
    let lastNode = root;

    while (l1 || l2 || carry) {
        let sum = carry;

        if(l1) {
            sum += l1.val;
            l1 = l1.next;
        }

        if(l2) {
            sum += l2.val;
            l2 = l2.next;
        }

        if (sum > 9) {
            carry = 1;
            sum = sum % 10;
        } else {
            carry = 0;
        }

        const node = new ListNode(sum);
        lastNode.next = node;
        lastNode = node;
    }
    return root.next;
};

console.log(addTwoNumbers([2, 4, 3], [5, 6, 4])); // [7, 0, 8]
  • Runtime: 141ms
  • Memory: 47.2MB

item.content:
Recursion Review

🔔 What is it for?

  • For accessing a nested data structure
  • Particularly useful when we do not know how many levels of nested arrays/objects there are
  • Recursion acts as a looping mechanism unto itself and leverages the callstack to complete its task

 

🔔 How Does It Works?

🌟 function recurson() { // <-- (2) Runs this recursion function script
    return ⚡recursion(); // <-- (3) Runs the inner recursion function
}
🌟 recursion(); // <-- (1) Starts from the global scope
NOTE: The recursion function is executed twice:
(1) ⚡ within the scope of our fuction
(2) 🌟outside in the global scope
  • We first execute the 🌟recursion function in the global scope
  • ➡️ it runs the 🌟recursion function script
  • ➡️ This calls the ⚡inner recursion function
  • ➡️ The inner recursion function runs the 🌟recursion function again
  • ➡️ Continues, adding recursion continously to our callstack, thereby creating a loop

 

🔔 Recursive Pattern

  • Base case is on the top, recursive case is below
  • We pass different arguments to recursive functions to move around the nested object
  // (1) what do you want to do for the current input?
    // case 1
    // case 2

  // (2) detect nestedness
    // iterate over that nested structure
      // recursively call our function on each value inside that array/obj (or childNode)

  // (3) forcefully send all values as a current input somewhere in the callstack

Example 1:

function recursion(num) {
  // base case
  if (num <= 0) {
    return 0;
  } else {
    // recursion execution
    return recursion(num - 1)
  }
}

recursion(5);
  • The output will be 0.
  • The inner recursion num - 1 continues the loop until num is 0.

Example 2:

function factorialSum(num) {
    if (num <= 0) {
        return 0;
    } else {
        return num + factorialSum(num - 1);
    }
}

factorialSum(5);
  • The output will be 15.
  • It starts by 5, the initial argument, getting added in memory to the callstack.
  • The recursion substracts 1 from the argument, so the new argument num is now 4, which gets added in memory to the callstack.
  • This continues until we reach the base case of 0.
  • ❗ Once we reach the base case, the callstack returns all the nested functions
    • ➡️ the stacked up execution contexts from each recursion gets popped off, returning from the last function called to the first function.
    • ➡️ 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15

 

🔔 Recursive Pattern for Infinitely Nested Arrays/Objects

We can also use recursion with a loop to handle infinitely nested arrays/objects.

Case 1: getElementsByClassName()

var getElementsByClassName = function(className) {
  var body = document.body;
  var result = [];

  // iterate over the htmlStrings
  var hasClassName = function(body) {
    // if each element has a class and the class is the same as className
    if (body.classList && body.classList.contains(className)) {
      // add the element to the result arr
      result.push(body);
    }

    // if the element has child node
    if (body.hasChildNodes()) {
      // iterate over child nodes
      for (var i = 0; i < body.childNodes.length; i++) {
        // use recursion to check if the child node has a class, which is the same as className
        hasClassName(body.childNodes[i]);
      }
    }
  };
  hasClassName(body);
  return result;
};

 

🔔 Recursion Problem Solving Tip

For every recursive solution, there’s an equal iterative solution. For coding challenges, first write out the iterative solution and use that to structure the recursive solution.

Iterative Solution:

// Input: Two numbers - a start and end value
// Output: [2, 3, 4, 5, 6] - an array that starts with startValue and ends with endValue

function inclusiveArrayParam(startValue, endValue) {
  const arr = [];
  for (let i = startValue; i <= endValue; i++) {
    arr.push(i);
  }
  return arr;
}

console.log('iterative inclusive array solution: ', inclusiveArrayParam(2,6));
  • Using a for loop, we’ve set i to the startValue and iterate it until it is less than or equal to endValue

Recursive Solution:

function inclusiveArrayParamRecursive(startValue, endValue) {
  // base case: consider the for loop condition
  if (startValue >= endValue) {
    return [startValue];
  } else {
    // recursive case
    const resultArr = inclusiveArrayParamRecursive(startValue, endValue - 1);
    resultArr.push(endValue);
    return resultArr;
  }
}

console.log('recursive inclusive array solution: ', inclusiveArrayParamRecursive(2, 6))
  • Base Case sets the loop paramenters to return startValue.
  • Once startValue equals endValue we return the callstack to unwind.

item.title: LeetCode: Two Sums - easy
item.description: Prompt Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order. Example: Input: nums = [2,7,11,15], target = 9 Output: [0,1] Explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].
item.content:
Prompt

Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.

Example: Input: nums = [2,7,11,15], target = 9 Output: [0,1] Explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].

Constraints:

  • 2 <= nums.length <= 104
  • -109 <= nums[i] <= 109
  • -109 <= target <= 109
  • Only one valid answer exists.

Can you come up with an algorithm that is less than O(n^2) time complexity?

A Quadratic Time Complexity Pattern: O(n^2)

Time Complexity

  • The time required to perform an algorithm
  • Described by the use of Big O notation

O(n^2)

  • O(n^2) = O(n * n) = the growth rate of n is n^2
  • A quadratic time complexity pattern
  • For nested for loop over an array of array

First Attemp

// declare an empty array for the result // iterate over the input array // iterate over the input array, starting with the consecutive value (index 1) // if target equals to the sum of each value from both iterations // push each index to the empty result array // return result array

var twoSum = function(nums, target) {
  var result = [];
  for (var i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
    for (var j = i + 1; j < nums.length; j++) {
      if (target == nums[i] + nums[j]) {
        result.push(i, j);
      }
    }
  }
  return result;
} // -> Runtime: 135ms, Memory: 42.2MB

Here j is used as a pointer to keep track of numbers in array. I’m also iterating over the entire array twice using a nested for loop. Although this solution works, the nested loop results in O(n^2) time complexity which will be very slow and prone to errors for a larger dataset.

Its current runtime and memory ussage are:

Runtime: 132ms Memory Usage: 42.3 MB

Optimized Soultion

A more optimized solution is to use object, similar to using the Hash Table implementation, which has a more efficient time complexity of O(n). If we hash all items and store them in a hash table, checking any element will be much faster regardless of the dataset size.

  1. Iterate over the input array
  2. The prompt indicates that each input has exactly one solution, so there is only one complementary number that can satisfy the return condition: x + y = target or target - y = x
  3. We are given the value of target as an input, and each time we iterate we get a value of y and we can calculate what x must be for the given y.
  4. In the empty hash object, we record the key and value:
  • key: target - y = target - nums[i] = value of x
  • value: i of nums[i] = index of y
  1. Check if the number exists
  • If it does exist, return both indices
  • Otherwise set the current index to i which is 0
var twoSum = function(nums, target) {
  var obj = {};
  for (var i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
    if (obj[nums[i]] >= 0) {
      return [obj[nums[i]], i];
    }
    obj[target - nums[i]] = i;
  }
} // -> Runtime: 88ms, Memory: 42.4MB

Compared to the first solution using a nested loop, using an object optimized the runtime by 47ms.

item.title: JavaScript Revision 3: HOF, Closure & Scope
item.description: 1. Fundamental Concept Value JavaScript has the scalar primitive types that are passed by value: Number, String, Boolean, undefined, null, and Symbol Values are stored in variables, a named unit of data Reference JavaScript has 3 data types that are passed by reference: Array, Function, and Objcet These are collectively known as Objects. Hoisting A JavaScript mechanism where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope before code execution.
item.content:
1. Fundamental Concept

Value

  • JavaScript has the scalar primitive types that are passed by value: Number, String, Boolean, undefined, null, and Symbol
  • Values are stored in variables, a named unit of data

Reference

  • JavaScript has 3 data types that are passed by reference: Array, Function, and Objcet
  • These are collectively known as Objects.

Hoisting

  • A JavaScript mechanism where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope before code execution.

 

2. Higher Order Functions / Callback Functions

Higher Order Function

  • A function that accepts functions as parameters and/or returns a function.

Callback Function

  • A function passed into another function as an argument.
  • This function can then be invoked during the execution of that higher order function.
  • This is possible because JavaScript functions are first class objects, so they can co-eixst with and can be treated like any other JavaScript object.
function copyArrayAndManipulate(array, instructions) {
  let output = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < array.length; i++) {
    output.push(instructions(array[i]));
  }
  return output;
}

function multiplyBy2(input) {
  return input * 2;
}

let result = copyArrayAndManipulate([1, 2, 3], multiplyBy2);

When do we use .map(), .filter() or .reduce()?

  • These methods iterate over an array and execute a callback function on each element.
  • This replaces a loop-based solution.
Method What It Does
.map() Returns a new array with the return values from the callback function, which may be different from the original array.
.filter() The callback function for each element must return either true or false. Returns a new array with elements for which the callback function returned true.
.reduce() Often used in state management. Returns a single value. It takes a callback function with two parameters accumulator and currentValue as arguments.
  • can we use reduce? with all data types as the accumulator input?

 

Closure and Scope

Lexical Scope / Static Scope

  • Defining a function creates a new lexical scope.
  • The place where an item got created (the definition area of an expression).

Execution Contexts

  • Calling a function creates a new execution context. It holds information about the environment within which the current code is being executed.

The Call Stack

  • Where execution contexts get stacked on top of each other to keep track of where we are in the program’s execution.
  • Each callstack will only ever return something to the previous callstack.

Closure

  • The combination of a function enclosed with references to its surrounding state (lexical environment).
  • Even after the outer (parent) function has closed, the inner function still has access to that parent scope.
  • Often used for object data privacy
  • In functional programming, closures are often used for partial application & currying.

Closure: memoization

.memoize only works because it uses a closure ✅

  • A form of caching where the return value of a function is cached based on its parameters.
  • With memoization we can store(cache) the computed results based on the parameters. If the same parameter is used again while invoking the function, instead of computing the result, we directly return the stored (cached) value.
  • The returned inner function will capture the cached values in its closure, which can be persisted through multiple calls.
  • While it optimizes the performance, it uses a larger consumption of memory since we are storing all the computed results (“trace space for speed trade-off”).
    • Unlike C, JavaScript doesn’t have a way to get the actual memory usage of an object
    • So the best way to limit the size of the cache is to go by the number of entires: if (cache.size > 1000) { cache.clear(); } cache.set(key, result);

Code example to show how this works

Example 1: A simplified version with primitives

function memoizedAddTo256() {
  var cache = {};

  return function(num) {
    if (num in cache) {
      console.log("cached value");
      return cache[num];
    } else {
      cache[num] = num + 256;
      return cache[num];
    }
  }
}

var memoizedFunc = memoizedAddTo256();

memoizedFunc(20); // Normal return
memoizedFunc(20); // Cached return

Example 2: How lodash memoize works

function memoize(fn, resolver) {
  const cache = new Map();

  const memoized = function(...args) {
    const key = resolver ? resolver.apply(null, args) : args[0];
    if (cache.has(key)) {
      return cache.get(key);
    } else {
      const result = fn.apply(null, args);
      cache.set(key, result);
      return result;
    }
  };

  memoized.getCache = () => cache;
  return memoized;
}

lodash/memoize.js, GitHub;

Memoized function in React

const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => computeExpensiveValue(a, b), [a, b]);

Closure function example

const getSecret = (secret) => {
  return {
    get: () => secret
  };
};

test('Closure for object privacy.', assert => {
  const msg = '.get() should have access to the closure.';
  const expected = 1;
  const obj = getSecret(1);

  const actual = obj.get();

  try {
    assert.ok(secret, 'This throws an error.');
  } catch (e) {
    assert.ok(true, `The secret var is only available
      to privileged methods.`);
  }

  assert.equal(actual, expected, msg);
  assert.end();
});

Closures can be used to create stateful functions whose return values may be influenced by their internal state:

const secret = msg => () => msg;

Closures: Functional Programming

Application

  • The process of applying a function to its arguments in order to produce a return value

Partial Application

  • The process of applying a function to some of its arguments.
  • The partially applied function gets returned for later use.
  • Partial application fixes one or more arguments inside the returned function, and the returned function takes the remaining parameters as argumetns in order to complete the function application.
const add = (a, b) => a + b;
const add10 = partialApply(add, 10);
add10(5);
  • The argument 10 becomes a fixed parameter remembered inside the add10 closure scope.

item.title: JavaScript Revision 2: Terms
item.description: Term Definition Execution context Holds information about the environment within which the current code is being executed; Calling a function creates a new execution context. An execution context always contains 3 parts: a variable environment, the scope chain in the current context, and this keyword. Call Stack Where execution contexts get stacked on top of each other to keep track of where we are in the program’s execution.
item.content:
Term Definition
Execution context Holds information about the environment within which the current code is being executed; Calling a function creates a new execution context. An execution context always contains 3 parts: a variable environment, the scope chain in the current context, and this keyword.
Call Stack Where execution contexts get stacked on top of each other to keep track of where we are in the program’s execution.
Variable environment The environment/region in the code which refers to the variables declared in each execution context.
Scope The space/environment where we can refer to a variable by name without getting access errors. There are 3 types of scopes: global scope, function scope, block scope
Local Scope Variables declared inside a function scope are only accessible inside that function.
Lexical Scoping The way variables are organized and accessed is entirely controlled by the placement of functions and blocks in the code. When a variable gets called by an inner function, the engine goes through the scope chain to find the lexical scope (origin) of the specific variable that got called.
Block Scope Refers to the scope of a variable declared inside any curly braces (e.g. a loop or if statement). let and const are block-scoped variables while var is function-scoped and accessible outside of the block. In strict mode, function are also block-scoped.
Scope Chain Refers to the link between scopes: each function defined has its own nested scope, and any function defined in another function has a local scope which is linked to the outer function. Scope Chain helps the engine to know which value is assigned to a specific variable name if there are multiples of them defined at different scopes. When resolving a variable, inner functions first look at their own scope. If the variable cannot be found in its own scope it will climb up the scope chain and look for the variable name in the environment where the function was defined. This process is called variable lookup. At the top of the scope chain is the global scope: window object for the browser and global for NodeJS.
Closure A retained scope. When you declare a function within another function, the outer function’s scope is accessible within the inner function. Global variables can be made local (private) with closures. It’s often used for data privacy.
Hoisting A JavaScript mechanism where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their scope before code execution. let and const are not hoisted; uninitialized.They are block-scoped, so they only exist in the block they were created; var gets hoisted to undefined.
Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) ES6: The region in the code where let or const variables cannot be accessed before its initialization. Accessing variables before the declaration is bad practice to be avoided. TDZ makes it easier to catch this by throwing an error.
An instance JavaScript is a prototype-based language with objects, so it does not differentiate between classes and instances unlike class-based languages (Java / C++). So in JS, instances informally means an object created using a particular constructor function. In class-based languages, instance is an individual instantiation of a class and is fundamentally different from a class.
.prototype A default container (object) for methods that is created with a function. It’s used for creating instances of a class. Use a prototype property to have a specific property accessible across all the objects. Every .prototype object has a .constructor property that points back to the function it came from. .prototype only works on functions. To access prototype property of an object (instance), use __proto__: both will refer to the same constructor function.
this An identifier for values designed to support object-oriented programming, created for every execution context. When you invoke a method (function as object’s property) or a constructor function, this points to the object calling the method (At the call time, look at the left of the dot notation). In strict mode, this in ‘normal’ functions will simply be undefined. But otherwise, it will point to the global object, which for browsers is the global object. For arrow functions, this becomes lexical, pointing to the value of this in the parent function. For event listener functions, this will always point to the DOM element the handler function is attached to.
new An operator that is placed before a constructor (function invocation), which runs the function as if there are these two extra lines of code at the beginning and the end: this: Object.create(___.prototype); … return this;
Constructor A class or function that specifies the type(name) of the object instance. JavaScript has only one constructor, objects. Each object has a private property which holds a link to another object called prototype.
Constructor function Functions that are used as templates for creating objects. Constructor function names commonly start with a capital letter. Uses the new operator to create a new instance of an object, which is referred to by this. Arrow functions cannot be used to define constructor functions. To check if we used new to call the constructor function, add console.log(new.target); in the constructor function.
Class A template for creating objects, replacing the previous method of using constructor functions. Commonly named with capitalized nouns. Two syntax: (1) Class Declaration: class Name { constructor(x) { this.x = …, } } (2) Class expression: let Name = class { constructor(x) { this.x = .. } }
instanceOf An operator that returns a boolean value to test if the prototype property of a constructor appears anywhere in the prototype chain of an object: objectName instanceof constructor
Decorator A design pattern of wrapping one piece of code with another, or applying a wrapper around a function to modify or add properties to enhance the functionality of the function without modifying the underlying function.
Object Decorator Pattern vs. Functional Class Pattern Object Decorator Pattern passes object as a parameter while Functional Class Pattern (the constructor functions) declares object inside the function
Pseudoclassical Class Instantiation Pattern Using a class in Pseudoclassical Style always calls a function with new in front of it. This pattern is a thin layer of syntactic convenience on top of the prototypal pattern.
Prototypal Pattern Describes what you need for a function that creates instances: (1) A line in a function where you create a new instance object (2) A delegation from the new object to some prototype (3) Some logic augmenting the new object with the properties that make it unique from other objects of the same class
Prototype Chains / Prototypal Inheritance Model Prototype chain is a mechanism for making objects resemble other objects by delegating its failed property lookup to that other object at lookup time. Object properties and methods can be inherited.
Object.create() Creates a new object with the specified prototype object and properties. Pass in a desired fallback object (which is a prototype object) to create a new object that delegates its failed lookups to the fallback object.
Object.assign() Creates a new object, but it’s a shallow copy and not a deep clone: it will only copy the properties in the first level while deep clone would copy everything.
Object Prototype A top-level object that every JavaScript object eventually delegates to. The object prototype provides the shared properties of all objects. This is where all the basic methods are provided. Its methods include .toString(), .constructor(), .hasOwnProperty()
Recursive Function A function that calls itself. All recursive functions have at least one base case: a case when the function can produce a result without recursing. All recursive functions have at least one recursive case. Recursion should not be utilized without an accompanying base case unless infinite operation is desired. To solve a problem, solve a subproblem that is a smaller instance of the same problem, and then use the solution to that smaller instance to solve the original problem.
Promise A JavaScript object that represents an eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation. You can achieve results from performing asynchronous operations using the callback approach or by using promises. Unlike callbacks where you pass a callback into a function, with promise you attach callbacks on the returned promise object. To perform multiple asynchronous operations simultaneously, promises are better practice as with callbacks we can easily end up in callback hell with unmanageable and hard-to-read codes. With promises, we can use the .then() method to chain the codes at the root of the first handler = Promise Chaining
Promise Chaining Useful when we need to execute a chain of asynchronous tasks. Each task that’s being chained can only start as soon as the previous task has completed, controlled by the .then() method of the chain.
async/await async: we can add async modifier in front of a function async function() { ... } / Await: wait for the promise to resolve; only works for asynchronous functions

item.title: JavaScript Revision 1: Terms
item.description: Term Definition Value JavaScript has the scalar primitive types that are passed by value: Number, String, Boolean, undefined, null, Symbol, and BigInt Reference JavaScript has 3 data types that are passed by reference: Array, Function, and Objcet Variable A named unit of data where values can be stored and referred to by that name Function The primary method through which we manipulate data in JavaScript.
item.content:
Term Definition
Value JavaScript has the scalar primitive types that are passed by value: Number, String, Boolean, undefined, null, Symbol, and BigInt
Reference JavaScript has 3 data types that are passed by reference: Array, Function, and Objcet
Variable A named unit of data where values can be stored and referred to by that name
Function The primary method through which we manipulate data in JavaScript. Functions are JavaScript’s first-class objects.
Undefined An unconfigurable, unwritable global property / A scalar variable without a scalar value assigned / A variable that has not been assigned a value yet is undefined / A function returns undefined if a value was not returned / A method or statement returns undefined if the variable that is being evaluated does not have an assigned value
Falsy False / 0 / “” / null / undefined / NaN
Null An intentional absence of any object value / Treated as Falsy for Boolean operations
NaN Not a Number: a floating-point value that does not represent a valid number; could be because we tried to combine a number with undefined
Parameter vs. Argument Parameters: the named variable passed into a function, which is used to import arguments into the function. / Arguments: the real values passed into the function.
String Strings are zero indexed and are immutable, but they can be reassigned from one string to another if we don’t use the variable name.
Scalar A single value or unit of data (e.g. undefined, boolean, number, string)
Array It is indeed an object! Arrays are zero indexed & are mutable.
Object A collection of properties: a property is an association between a name (key) and value (type of data). Arrays and Functions are objects.
Method Function(s) that are stored as object properties. Array.prototype.methodName() Function.prototype.methodName() Object.prototype.methodName()
Method invocation When I call a function that is the property of an object
Number.parseInt() Takes a string version of a number and returns a real number
Number.parseFloat() Takes a string version of a decimal and returns a real decimal
Math.random() Generates a random number between 0 and 1 / If I want a random number between 2 specific values: Math.random() * (max - min) + min
String Interpolation A process of embedding an expression into part of a string.
.substring() Method for accessing a portion of a string
.indexOf() Returns the position of the first occurrence of a specified value in a string.
Escape Characters Special characters that invoke an alternative interpretation on subsequent characters in a character sequence: \’ for escaping an apostrophe & \n for newline character
.push() Adds an element to the back of an array
.pop() Removes the last element of an array and returns that element
.unshift() Adds an element to the front of an existing array
.shift() Removes an element from the front of an existing array
.splice() Removes, replaces, or adds element(s) in an array.
.slice() Makes a copy of an array or a specific section of an array without altering the original array
delete Operator that removes a property from an existing object / A deleted property returns undefined
Object.keys() Method that returns an array of an object’s property names (keys)
Object.values() Method that return an array of all values in a given object
Iteration vs Loop Iteration: the process in which the code segment is executed once; one iteration refers to one time execution of a loop. / Loop: a segment of code that executes multiple times; A loop can undergo many iterations.
Loop in reverse for (var i = array.length - 1; i > -1; i --)
A lookup When we return/log an object property to get its value. return varName.key varName.key is a lookup for the key
.call() & .apply() A function.prototype method used to invoke a function immediately with modification of the context. .call() passes strings as its arguments while .apply() passes arrays as its arguments.
.bind() A function.prototype method that creates a new bound function, which is useful in events. No matter how this bound function is called, it’s called with a particular this value.

item.title: The Runtime Environment: Call Stack & Heap
item.description: The Engine and Runtime The JavaScript engine always contains a call stack and a heap. Call Stack JavaScript code runs in the call stack. The call stack is where execution contexts get stacked on top of each other to keep track of where we are in the program’s execution. The execution context on top of the stack is the one that’s currently running. When it’s finished running, it will be removed from the stack, and execution will go back to the previous execution context.
item.content:
The Engine and Runtime

The JavaScript engine always contains a call stack and a heap.

Call Stack

JavaScript code runs in the call stack.

The call stack is where execution contexts get stacked on top of each other to keep track of where we are in the program’s execution. The execution context on top of the stack is the one that’s currently running. When it’s finished running, it will be removed from the stack, and execution will go back to the previous execution context.

More about execution context…

After compilation, the code is ready to be executed. At this moment, a global execution context is created for the top-level code, which refers to the code that is not inside any function (*the code inside functions will only get executed when the functions are called).

While there’s only one global execution context, a new execution context gets created for every function call. All of these execution contexts make up the call stack. Every execution context has a variable environment, which stores the variables and function declarations and arguments object, which is an array (object) that contains all the arguments that were passed into the function when it was called.

Memory Creation Phase

When a new execution context is created on a function call, the JavaScript engine configures it for execution. During this memory creation phase, the following are created.

  1. A scope
  2. A scope chain
  3. Determination of the value of this

To note, arrow functions do not have the arguments object and this keyword.

Heap

is an unstructured memory pool that stores all the objects our application needs.

Just-In-Time Compilation

Every computer programs are converted into machine code using compilation or interpretation.

  • Compilation: the entire source code is converted into machine code at once. This is then written into a portable file that can be executed on any computer.
  • Interpretation: an interpreter runs through the source code and executes it line by line. The code is read and executed all at the same time.

JavaScript used to be a purely interpreted language, but this was much slower than compiled languages.

The modern JavaScript uses a mix between compilation and interpretation called Just-In-Time compilation. This approach compiles the entire code into machine code at once and then executes it right away, which proved to be much faster than executing code line by line. The following is a simplified breakdown of the overall process:

  1. Parsing

    • The JavaScript engine parses (reads) the code as it enters the engine.
    • During this process, the code is parsed into a data structure called the Abstract Syntax Tree.
    • Each line of code gets splitted up into pieces, such as const or function keywords.
    • These are then saved into the tree in a structured manner (not related to the DOM tree!).
    • The resulting tree represents the entire code inside the engine.

  2. Compilation

    • After this parsing process, the generated AST is compiled into machine code.
    • The machine code gets executed right away because the JavaScript engine uses just-in-time compilation.

  3. Optimization

    • Without stopping the execution, the code is optimized and recompiled as many times as needed.
    • After each optimization, the initial unoptimized code is swept for the new, more optimized code.

Note: This entire process takes place in a special thread that is separate from the main thread which is running in the call stack executing the code.

A Runtime Environment

JavaScript runtime environment is where the program will be executed. There are two types of runtime environments where different data values and functions are available. These differences distinguish front-end applications from back-end applications.

  1. A browser’s runtime environment
  • Front-end JavaScript applications are executed in a browser’s runtime environment.
  • Have access to the window object, through which JavaScript gets access to Web APIs for DOM, Timers, Fetch API, etc.
  • Alongside the engine, Web APIs, the runtime also includes callback queue
    • Callback queue is a data structure containing all the callback functions that are ready to be executed
    • Event handler functions like onClick is a callback function to DOM element, a button for instance.
    • When the event is fired, the callback function is put into the callback queue.
    • Then via the event loop, the callback function from the callback queue is passed to the stacks to be executed when the stack is empty.
  1. The Node runtime environment
  • Back-end JavaScript applications are executed in the Node runtime environment.
  • Have access to the file system, databases, and networks attached to the server, which are unavailable in a browser.
  • Have multiple C++ bindings and a thread pool.

item.content:
High-level languages, such as JavaScript and Python, have abstractions so that we don’t need to manage resources (i.e. memory/CPU) like we do for low level languages like C.

Garbage Collection

One of the powerful tools in JavaScript that takes away the memory management from developers is garbage collection. It’s an algorithm inside the JavaScript engine that automatically removes old and unused objects from the computer memory.

Interpreted / Just-in-time Compiled Language

The JavaScript code we write is a human-readable abstraction over machine code, which needs to be compiled/interpreted to machine code that is understood by the computer’s processor (only zeros and ones!). This process takes inside the JavaScript engine, making it an interpreted or just-in-time compiled language.

To note, this compilation/interpretation step is necessary for every single programming language!

Multi-paradigm Language

A paradigm is an approach and an overall mindset of structuring our code, which directs the overall coding style and techniqe.

While many languages are only procedural, object-oriented, or functional, JavaScript does all of them. We can decide which paradigm we want to use. The three most popular paradigms are:

  • Procedural programming: organizing the code in a linear way with some functions in between
  • Object-oriented programming (OOP): the prototype-based, object-oriented approach considers everything in JavaScript as an object except for primitive values such as numbers, strings, etc.
  • Functional programming (FP): JavaScript is a language with first-class functions, which means that they are treated as regular variables. We can pass functions into other functions and return functions from functions.

Dynamic Language

We don’t assign data types to variables. Instead, they only become known at runtime when the JavaScript engine executes the code. The type of variables can also be easily changed as we reassign variables, making JavaScript a dynamically-typed language.

Concurrency model and Event Loop

JavaScript has a runtime model based on an event loop, which is responsible for executing the code, collecting and processing events, and executing queued sub-tasks.

item.content:
What is it?

  • SQL: Structured Query Language
  • Lets us access and manipulate databases, such as:
    • executing queries against a database
    • retrieving data from a database
    • inserting a record in a database
    • updating records in a database
    • deleting records from a database
    • creating new databases
    • creating new tables in a database
    • creating stored procedures in a database
    • creating views in a database
    • setting permissions on tables, procedures, and views

Major Commands

  • These are not case sensitive
  • SELECT - extracts data from a database
  • FROM - specifies the parent database
  • WHERE - filters records according to the given condition
    • <> or !=: not equal
    • BETWEEN: between a certain range
    • LIKE: search for a pattern
    • IN: specifies multiple possible values for a column
  • ORDER BY - organize in a default order
  • ASC or DESC - organize in ascending or descending order
  • DISTINCT - display the specified data only (e.g. SELECT DISTINCT)
  • UPDATE - updates data in a database
  • DELETE - deletes data from a database
  • INSERT INTO - inserts new data into a database
  • CREATE DATABASE / CREATE TABLE - creates a new database/table
  • ALTER DATABASE / ALTER TABLE - modifies a database/table
  • DROP TABLE - deletes tables
  • CREATE INDEX - creates an index (search key)
  • DROP INDEX - deletes an index

References

DataCamp

item.title: Semantic Versioning
item.description: Semantic Versioning (SemVer) A versioning system for software releases, such as new plugins, addons, libraries, and extensions. It consists of 3 components in the format of X.Y.Z X: Major Version When the major version number is increased, the minor and patch version numbers are reset to zero. Increasing the major number breaks the existing API. Y: Minor Version Minor version indicates the release of new functionality in the system (when implementing new features in a backwards-incompatible way).
item.content:
Semantic Versioning (SemVer)

A versioning system for software releases, such as new plugins, addons, libraries, and extensions.

It consists of 3 components in the format of X.Y.Z

X: Major Version

  • When the major version number is increased, the minor and patch version numbers are reset to zero.
  • Increasing the major number breaks the existing API.

Y: Minor Version

  • Minor version indicates the release of new functionality in the system (when implementing new features in a backwards-incompatible way).
  • When this is increased, the patch version number is reset to zero.
  • Does not break the existing API.

Z: Patch Version

  • For bug fixes; no functionality changes.
  • There’s no limit to patch version numbers.

Important Notes

  • The first version starts at 0.1.0 not 0.0.1
  • The first stable version is 1.0.0.
  • Before 1.0.0 is the Development Phase for Beta versions.
  • Additional labels for pre-release and build metadata are available as extensions to the MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH format.

References

Cyren, Tierney. “The Basics of Package.json in Node.js and npm”, Nodesource, March 3, 2017.

“Introduction to Semantic Versioning”, GeeksforGeeks, Auguest 17, 2021.

“Semantic Versioning 2.0.0”, Semver

item.title: Systems
item.description: Webpage Rendering HTML is received from the server and processed into the DOM. The styles are loaded and parsed into the CSSOM. The render tree is created using the DOM and CSSOM. The browser creates a layout for each render tree element with its individual coordinates using the flow method, which requires just one pass to layout all the elements, compared to the tables method that requires more than one pass.
item.content:
Webpage Rendering

  1. HTML is received from the server and processed into the DOM.
  2. The styles are loaded and parsed into the CSSOM.
  3. The render tree is created using the DOM and CSSOM.
  4. The browser creates a layout for each render tree element with its individual coordinates using the flow method, which requires just one pass to layout all the elements, compared to the tables method that requires more than one pass.
  5. The information is displayed in the browser window in its final form through the last stage of the process, also known as painting.

Repaint

Repaint is a technique that allows the browser to update the appearance of the elements of the webpage without changing the layout, such as the background color, outline of the element, or its visibility.

Reflow

Reflow takes place when the change to the webpage affects the layout of the page and the position of its elements. Reflow will recalculate the position of all the elements in the DOM, including the child and the parent components, even if the changes concern a single element. Reflow can be triggered by:

  • manipulating the elements of the DOM
  • changes in the content (including the form field content)
  • changes in the CSS properties
  • adding or removing style sheets
  • changing the class attributes
  • resizing the browser window
  • scrolling
  • pseudo-class action such as :hover

Optimization

Both repaint and reflow slows down the performance of a webpage, especially reflow.

Method 1: Restricting the areas where repaint or reflow take place. Method 2: Caching the changes while running JavaScript and applying the changes in a single pass after the code run has finished.

var $body = $('body');
  $body.css('padding', '1px'); // reflow, repaint
  $body.css('color', 'red'); // repaint
  $body.css('margin', '2px'); // reflow, repaint

Same-origin

Modern web browsers provide many built-in security mechanisms to defent against attackers. Some of these include:

  • Same-origin policy
  • Cookie Policy
  • Content Security Policy
  • Browser sandbox
  • XSS protection, etc.

The origin in this context refers to the exact location of a specific resource, such as image or script. It consists of three main elements:

  1. The protocol: HTTP or HTTPS
  2. The hostname: developer.mozilla.org
  3. The port: 80, 443, 8080, etc.

When the browser performs the same-origin policy checks, it compares the originating location with the location of the requested resource.

Its purpose is to restrict cross-origin interactions between documents, scripts, or media files from one origin to a web page with a different origin.

The rise of JavaScript and the DOM API to support interactive sites caused security concerns, such as Cross-Site Request Forgery where a malicious site can read a user’s private info with Asynchronous JavaScript and XML (AJAX) requests. To address such concerns, Netscape introduced the same-origin policy to prevent cross-origin resources from being accessed.

However, this is by no means a perfect solution. In some cases, it’s not restrictive enough while in other caess, it’s too restrictive and complicates the workflow of a web application. As a response to this, CORS was introduced.

CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)

CORS allows servers to specify trusted origins that can be used in cross-origin requests, although multiple whitelisted domains cannot be specified. A CORS requests can be either Simple or Preflight. More on this below.

The CORS standard works by adding new HTTP headers that let servers describe which origins (domain, scheme, or port) are permitted to read that information from a web browser.

An example of a cross-origin request: the front-end JavaScript code served from https://domain-a.com uses XMLHttpRequest to make a request for https://domain-b.com/data.json.

CORS failures result in errors but for security reasons, specifics about the error are not available to JavaScript. All the code knows is that an error occurred. The only way to determine what specifically went wrong is to look at the browser’s console for details.

Examples of access control scenarios include:

1. Simple requests

Some requests don’t trigger a CORS preflight. A simple request is one that meets all the following conditions:

  • One of the allowed methods: GET, HEAD, POST
  • Apart from the headers automatically set by the user agent, the only headers which are allowed to be manually set are those which the Fetch spec defines as a CORS-safelisted request-header, which are: Accept, Accept-Langauge, Content-Language, Content-Type.
  • The only type/subtype combinations allowed for the media type specified in the Content-Type header are: application/x-www-form-urlencoded, multipart/form-data, text/plain
  • If the request is made using an XMLHttpRequest object, no event listeners are registered on the object returned by the XMLHttpRequest.upload property used in the request; that is, given an XMLHttpRequest instance xhr, no code has called xhr.upload.addEventListener() to add an event listener to monitor the upload.
  • No ReadableStream object is used in the request.
GET /courses HTTP/1.1
Host: api.developer.mozilla.org
Origin: https://www.developer.mozilla.org
...
And the server responds with:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://www.developer.mozilla.org
Content-Type: application/json
...

2. Preflighted requests

  • The browser first sends an HTTP request using the OPTIONS method to the resource on the other origin, in order to determine if the actual request is safe to send.
  • Such cross-origin requests are preflighted since they may have implications for user data.
const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.open('POST', 'https://bar.other/resources/post-here/');
xhr.setRequestHeader('X-PINGOTHER', 'pingpong');
xhr.setRequestHeader('Content-Type', 'application/xml');
xhr.onreadystatechange = handler;
xhr.send('<person><name>Arun</name></person>');

3. Requests with credentials

  • These are aware of HTTP cookies and HTTP Authentication information.
  • By default, in cross-origin XMLHttpRequest or Fetch invocations, browsers will not send credentials.
  • A specific flag has to be set on the XMLHttpRequest object or the Request constructor when it is invoked.

References

“Chapter 14: The Document Object Model”, Eloquent JavaScript

“Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)”, MDN Web Docs

Daityari, Shaumik. “Working With and Around the Same-Origin Policy”, sitepoint, February 28, 2014.

“Document loading and DOM lifecycle events”, Jimmy Breck-McKye, April 21, 2014.

Frontend Dev, “Webpage Rendering: How It Works + Tips on Optimization”, Qarea, October 13, 2020.

Garsiel, Tali. Irish, Paul. “How Browsers Work: Behind the scenes of modern web browsers”, HTML5Rocks, August 5, 2011.

“Max parallel http connections in a browser?”, Developer Blog, March 24, 2015.

“Same-Origin Policy and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing(CORS)”, Hack EDU

item.description: What is client-side validation? It refers to providing feedbacks to users so that they can give us the correct information. e.g. “your password must be at least 8 characters” or “this field is required.” HTML5 Form Validation Form validaiton is a large part of project-specific, dependent on business logic. Input Types <form> <label>Name (required)</label> <input type="text" name="name"> <label>Email (required)</label> <input type="text" name="email"> <label>Age (required, must be older than 13)</label> <input type="text" name="age"> <label>Number of siblings</label> <input type="text" name="siblings"> <label>Number of rooms in your house</label> <input type="text" name="rooms"> <label>Blog url</label> <input type="text" name="blog"> <label>Twitter Username</label> <input type="text" name="twitter"> <input type="submit"> </form> HTML5 Constraint API HTML5 constraint validation API helps developers avoid use of JavaScript for simple validations.
item.content:
What is client-side validation?

It refers to providing feedbacks to users so that they can give us the correct information.

e.g. “your password must be at least 8 characters” or “this field is required.”

HTML5 Form Validation

Form validaiton is a large part of project-specific, dependent on business logic.

Input Types

<form>
    <label>Name (required)</label>
    <input type="text" name="name">
    <label>Email (required)</label>
    <input type="text" name="email">
    <label>Age (required, must be older than 13)</label>
    <input type="text" name="age">

    <label>Number of siblings</label>
    <input type="text" name="siblings">

    <label>Number of rooms in your house</label>
    <input type="text" name="rooms">

    <label>Blog url</label>
    <input type="text" name="blog">

    <label>Twitter Username</label>
    <input type="text" name="twitter">
    <input type="submit">
</form>

HTML5 Constraint API

HTML5 constraint validation API helps developers avoid use of JavaScript for simple validations.

Validation based attributes

  1. pattern

<input type=”text” pattern=”[1-4]{5}” />

  1. required

<input type=”text” required />

  1. maxlength

<input type=”text” maxlength=”20” />

  1. min & max

  2. onchange

<form name="ValidationForm">
	Password: <input type="password" id="password1"/>
	Confirm Password:<input type="password" id="password2"/>
	<input type="submit" value="submit"/>
</form>

“Whenever a change event is fired, we need to check if both of the passwords match. If yes, we call setCustomValidity() on the input element (password field in this case) with an empty string as the argument. On the other hand, if we detect that the passwords don’t match in a change event we call setCustomValidity() with an error message as argument. It means the password field will be marked as invalid and the error message will be shown when the user submits the form.”

<script type="text/javascript">
 window.onload = function () {
   document.getElementById("password1").onchange = validatePassword;
   document.getElementById("password2").onchange = validatePassword;
 }

 function validatePassword(){
 var pass2=document.getElementById("password2").value;
 var pass1=document.getElementById("password1").value;
 if(pass1!=pass2)
   document.getElementById("password2").setCustomValidity("Passwords Don't Match");
 else
   document.getElementById("password2").setCustomValidity('');
 //empty string means no validation error
 }
</script>

A Sample Form

<form id="myForm">
  <div class="form-group">
    <label for="email">
      Email<span class="required">*</span>
    </label>
    <!-- Email should be required and validate for a correct email. -->
    <input type="text" required="required" class="form-control" id="email">
  </div>

  <div class="form-group">
    <label for="password">
      Password<span class="required">*</span>
       <span class="info">(Minimum Length of 8 Characters)</span>
    </label>
    <!-- Password is required and must be at least 8 characters that are hidden when typed. -->
    <input type="text" minlength="8" class="form-control" id="password">
  </div>

  <div class="form-group">
    <label for="website">My Website</label>
    <!-- Website is optional but if it is there should be validated as a real URL. -->
    <input type="url" class="form-control" id="website" placeholder="http://...">
  </div>

  <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary">Submit</button>

</form>

Validating against a regular expression (regex)

Another useful validation feature is the pattern attribute, which expects a Regular Expression as its value. A regular expression (regex) is a pattern that can be used to match character combinations in text strings, so regexps are ideal for form validation and serve a variety of other uses in JavaScript.

In JavaScript, regular expressions are also objects. These patterns are used with the exec() and test() methods of RegExp, and with the match(), matchAll(), replace(), replaceAll(), search(), and split() methods of String.

<form>
  <label for="choose">Would you prefer a banana or a cherry?</label>
  <input id="choose" name="i_like" required pattern="[Bb]anana|[Cc]herry">
  <button>Submit</button>
</form>

REMEMBER: <textarea> element does not support the pattern attribute.

Validating with JavaScript

Common Steps:

  1. Select the value of the input(s) you’re testing while the input(s) is being changed or on submit
  2. Run some kind of check against it
  3. If there’s an error, surface it the user
  4. If there’s not an error, continue

Using Vanilla JavaScript vs jQuery to access form inputs

// vanilla javascript
var form = document.querySelector('#some-form');
var input = document.querySelector('#some-input');

document.forms; // Get all forms on a page
form.elements; // Get all form elements
input.type.toLowerCase(); // Get input type (radio, checkbox, text, etc.)
input.value; // Get input value
input.name; // Get input name
input.checked; // Get the checked status of a checkbox or radio button
input.disabled; // Get input disabled status

// jQuery
var form = $('#some-form');
var input = $('#some-input');

input.val(); // Get input value
input.getAttr("name"); // Get input name
input[0].checked; // Get the checked status of a checkbox or radio button
input[0].disabled; // Get input disabled status

Using jQuery to access values:

// 1. access values on submit: "submit"
$("#myForm").on("submit", function(){
    // do entire form validation here
})

// 2. access values as soon as a user is done typing: "blur"
$("#myInput").on("blur", function(){
    // do single input validation here
})

Handling Errors:

A typical pattern is to display either next to the incorrectly filled out element, or a the top of the form, a new DOM element that lists the error in question.

When you bind an event handler to something that has a default action, the handler will fire and then the default action will happen. To stop this, we can use event.preventDefault(); or call return false from within a jQuery event handler.

$("#myForm").on("submit", function(){

    if (some_error_condition) {

        var errDiv = $('<div class="error">Please fix your phone number</div>')

        $("#myForm").append(errDiv);

        return false; // This tells the submission not to happen
    }
})

Cleave.js

Cleave.js is a useful library to format input contents when you are typing!

Example: Auto-capitalization

<div class="container">
  <div class="row">
    <div class="col">
      <h1>Auto-capitalize</h1>
      <hr>
      <form id="myForm">
        <div class="form-group">
          <label for="title">Add a Book Title</label>
          <input type="text" class="form-control" id="title">
        </div>
      </form>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
	var input = document.getElementById('title')
  input.addEventListener('keyup', function (event) {
  	var text = event.target.value
    var textArray = text.split(' ')
    var titlecaseArray = textArray.map(function (word) {
    	return word ? word[0].toUpperCase() + word.slice(1) : ''
    })
    var titlecase = titlecaseArray.join(' ')

    event.target.value = titlecase
  })
})

Points of Discussion

  • Why do we need to do form validation inside an event listener?

To perform more complex validation on form input values.

  • What is a better experience for the user: using the required attribute, or using JS to ensure all required fields are checked?

“For good user experience, indicate to the user when form fields are required. It isn’t only good user experience, it is required by WCAG accessibility guidelines. Also, only require users to input data you actually need: For example, why do you really need to know someone’s gender or title?”

  • Why might browser validation not be enough?

Client-side validation is not enough because its scope of action is strict and is only performed in the browser user-interface. A web server ‘listens’ to and receives an HTTP request containing data from the browser, and then process it. It places trust in the browser, an entity that should never be trusted. It should only be used to improve user experience and application performance by catching malformed input on the client and saving a roundtrip to the server.

Client-side validation should never be used for security purposes. It can be easily bypassed and does not prevent malicious attacks. All input should be validated server side. We can also place a server-side validator for all inputs. The following steps outline how to properly set the validation routines:

  1. Identify input: Determine the data that is to be passed from the client to your application, such as URL-based parameters, form-based parameters, hidden fields, and cookies.
  2. Understand the use and constraints associated with each input. Define the format and type of each input. Build a server-side validator for each format and type of expected input.
  3. Create a set of validators for each type of input on the server-side of the application. If there are validators on the client-side, make sure the same validators are implemented on the server-side as well.

References

“25.9. Validation with JavaScript”, Launch Code Education

“Client-side form validation”, MDN Web Docs

“Constraint validation”, MDN Web Docs

“Ditching jQuery”, Go Make Things, August 25, 2014

“Dive Into HTML5”

“HTML5 Pattern”

“HTML attribute reference”, MDN Web Docs

Panda, Sandeep. “Using the HTML5 Constrint API for Form Validation”, sitepoint, August 22, 2013.

“Regular expressions”, MDN Web Doc

Truth, Serge. “Do Not Rely on Client-Side Validation”, Security Innovation, July 26, 2011.

item.title: Local Storage
item.description: Definition of Local Storage a browser API that allows a web application to persist its state inside a user’s web browser can be used to persist information retrieved from sources like user events, HTTP responses, and calculated results only persists strings has no expiration time until explicitly cleared improves a web application’s user experience more data can be stored in localStorage than in cookies Data model: the software representation of information Data persistence: store data in the application so that when a user comes back to the site, they can pick up from where they left off
item.content:
Definition of Local Storage

  • a browser API that allows a web application to persist its state inside a user’s web browser
  • can be used to persist information retrieved from sources like user events, HTTP responses, and calculated results
  • only persists strings
  • has no expiration time until explicitly cleared
  • improves a web application’s user experience
  • more data can be stored in localStorage than in cookies

Data model: the software representation of information Data persistence: store data in the application so that when a user comes back to the site, they can pick up from where they left off

How it works in a web browser:

localStorage.setItem('favoriteFood', 'Canned corn');

// Quit the application

// Launch the application

localStorage.getItem('favoriteFood');  // 'Canned corn'

To persist state, the application provides local storage a key and a value. To retrieve state, the application provides local storage the same key.

Restrictions

  1. State persisted to local storage is only available to pages on the same domain. If state is persisted for favoritefoods.com then it cannot be retrieved for favorite-foods.com.
  2. State persisted to local storage is only available using the same web browser. If state is persisted using Chrome then it cannot be retrieved using Firefox, and vice versa.
  3. Local storage only persists strings. If an application’s state contains any other data type, it must be serialized to a string when it’s saved and deserialized back to its original data type when it’s retrieved.
  4. Local storage has a limit of 5 MB, or 2.5 million characters, per domain.

CRUD operations on items in local storage

CRUD stands for Create / Read / Update / Delete.

Create

In Chrome DevTools:

  • Click the Application tab
  • Click the arrow next to the ‘Local Storage’ section on the sidebar
  • Click the child underneath the ‘Local Storage’ section

To create an item in local storage, pass a key and a value to the localStorage.setItem() method.

localStorage.setItem('favoriteString', 'Canned corn');  // 'Canned corn'
localStorage.setItem('favoriteNumber', 42);             // '42'
localStorage.setItem('favoriteBoolean', true);          // 'true'

When creating items in local storage from an object or array, use the JSON.stringify() method to serialize the state first.

localStorage.setItem('favoriteObject', JSON.stringify({ a: 1, b: 2 }));  // '{ "a": 1, "b": 2 }'
localStorage.setItem('favoriteArray', JSON.stringify([1, 2, 3]));        // '[1,2,3]'
localStorage.setItem('favoriteBoolean', JSON.stringify(true));           // 'true'

Read

To read an item from local storage, pass a key to the localStorage.getItem() method. Then, use the JSON.parse() method to deserialize any state that’s been serialized.

const favoriteString = localStorage.getItem('favoriteString');

const favoriteNumber = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteNumber'));
const favoriteBoolean = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteBoolean'));
const favoriteObject = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteObject'));
const favoriteArray = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteArray'));

When attempting to read a local storage item, sometimes null is returned because it hasn’t been created. For example, the first time a user launches an application. For these cases, it’s wise to initialize the application’s state with a default value. This is where the || operator can be useful. The || operator returns the value on the left, if it’s truthy, otherwise it returns the value on the right.

const favoriteString = localStorage.getItem('favoriteString') || '';
const favoriteNumber = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteNumber')) || 0;
const favoriteBoolean = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteBoolean')) || false;
const favoriteObject = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteObject')) || {};
const favoriteArray = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteArray')) || [];

Update

First, use the localStorage.getItem() method, or a default value, to initialize state. When an event is triggered, handle it by updating the state and then updating local storage with the localStorage.setItem() method, which will completely replaces an item.

// initialize state
let favoriteObject = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('favoriteObject')) || { votes: 0 };

$('button').on('click', () => {
  // update state
  favoriteObject.votes += 1;

  // update local storage
  localStorage.setItem('favoriteObject', JSON.stringify(favoriteObject));
});

Destroy

localStorage.removeItem('favoriteObject');

References

Coyier, Chris. “Examples of Sites where localStorage should or is being used”, CSS-Tricks, July 27, 2011.

“Storage”, MDN Web Docs

“The past, present & future of local storage for web applications”, Dive Into HTML5

“Window.localStorage”, MDN Web Docs

item.content:
JSON: JavaScript Object Notation

JSON, or JavaScript Object Notation, is a minimal, readable format for structuring data. It is used primarily to transmit data between a server and web application, as an alternative to XML.

JSON can be parsed by a standard JavaScript function, and is parsed into a ready-to-use JavaScript object. It is thus faster and easier than XML.

To read from JSON, we need to first use fs to read in the file as text(strings) and then `JOSN.parse() to convert it.

const fs = require('fs')
const contentsInJSON = fs.readFileSync('/path/to/my/file.json', 'utf-8')
const contentsAsJS = JSON.parse(contentsInJSON)

To write back to JSON, use JSON.stringify()

const fs = require('fs')
const contents = [ { id: 1, name: 'Intro to JSON' } ]
const contentsAsJSON = JSON.stringify(contents)
fs.writeFileSync('/path/to/my/json.file', contentsAsJSON)

XML & HTML

Both XML and HTML are markup langauges.

XML: Extensible Markup Language (meta-language of noting/marking)

  • developed to describe data and to focalize on what the data represent
  • tags are not pre-defined, so they need to be created according to the needs
  • it is not a substitute for HTML
    • it can store data separately from HTML
    • it can be used to store data inside the HTML documents as ‘data islands’
    • can be used to store data in files and databases

HTML

  • developed to display data about to focalize on the way that data looks
  • pre-defined tags

The cheerio library allows us to parse XML and HTML through Node.js. It can be used for reading XML data or parsing websites.

CSV: comma-separated values

CSV files are not just separated by commas, but also tabs or delimiter.

It’s powerful because it can be read in many formats.
